Home Diet&Nutrition Food&Health Not Eating Healthy Reasons Not to Eat Fast Foods
Reasons Not to Eat Fast Foods Oct 13, 2010 | By August McLaughlin Photo Credit tasty burger image by Alexey Klementiev from Fotolia.com Though eating fast food on occasion is unlikely to pose harm, frequent intake is linked with health risks. For optimum wellness, the American Dietetic Association recommends a diet based upon nutritious, whole foods, such as fruits, vegetables, whole grains, lean protein sources and healthy fats. Cooking healthy foods can save money and heighten appreciation for basic foods. There are many reasons not to eat fast food.
Trans Fats
Trans fats are fats produced through a process in which hydrogen is added to vegetable oil to create a longer-lasting, solid form fat source. Trans fats can harm your health in several negative ways, according to the American Heart Association. In addition to increasing your LDL, or "bad" cholesterol, trans fats may reduce your HDL, or "good" cholesterol. Fast food restaurant items are major sources of trans fats. Since fast food restaurants are not required to list trans fat content on menus, it is possible to consume excessive amounts of unhealthy fats without realizing it. Fast food items particularly high in trans fats include french fries, fried fish filet sandwiches, fried chicken, fruit-filled pies and pastries, cookies, crackers, tortilla chips, refried beans, hard taco shells and potato chips.
Overeating
Fast food increases the risk of eating excessive calories, fat, cholesterol and overall food portions. According to "Fat Land," by journalist Greg Critser, people tend to consume more food when excessive portions are available. The fast food trend of "super sizing" french fries or soft drinks for a low monetary price can instill a false sense of hunger and cause consumers to "feast," according to Critser. For example, a patron may enter a fast food restaurant intending to purchase one hamburger and a side salad only to feel swayed by bargain prices and the visual appeal of large, reasonably price portions of less healthy foods. The more often a person overeats fast food, the more likely he is to repeat the behavior and experience cravings for less healthy fare.
Reduced Nutrient Intake
Eating fast food is associated with reduced nutrient intake and heightened risk for numerous medical conditions. According to research involving 1,033 Minnesota residents, published in the "International Journal of Behavioral Nutrition and Physical Activity" in 2006, people who eat fast food regularly tend to consume fewer vegetables and more fat than people who do not. Fast food partakers also tend to exercise less. A low-nutrient, high-fat diet and low physical activity are associated with increased risk for high cholesterol, high blood pressure, heart attack, stroke, certain forms of cancer and heart disease. Fast food restaurants scarcely provide vegetables, other than iceberg lettuce, tomatoes and potatoes --- which are usually deep-fried. Consuming few antioxidants in the form of colorful fruits and vegetables can lead to poor immune system function and more frequent colds, bouts with the flu and numerous other infections and diseases.
References
American Heart Association: Know Your Fats "Fat Land: How Americans Became the Fattest People in the World"; Greg Critser; 2004 "International Journal of Behavioral Nutrition and Physical Activity"; Robert W Jeffery et al.; 2006 American Dietetic Association: Heart Health and Diet
